article.title: Research Note: The Expected Spins of Gravitational Wave Sources With Isolated Field Binary Progenitors

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the relationship between various timescales and binary separation for systems with a Wolf-Rayet (WR) star and a black hole (BH). What can you infer from the steep dependence of  t_merge and t_tr on separation (d)?
choices: The transition between tidal torques being important (t_tr << t_WR) and unimportant (t_tr >> t_WR) occurs over a large range of separations.
The transition between tidal torques being important and unimportant is highly sensitive to the details of the system.
The location where tidal torques become important (d_tr) is significantly different from the distance needed for the binary to merge in a Hubble time (d_merge).
The transition between tidal torques being important and unimportant occurs over a very small range of separations.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the spin parameter of a tidally locked WR star (a_sync) as a function of separation. What is the main takeaway from this figure?
choices: Tidally locked WR stars generally have low angular momentum compared to a maximally rotating BH of the same mass.
The spin parameter of the WR star increases linearly with increasing binary separation.
The mass of the WR star has a negligible effect on its spin parameter at a given separation.
Tidally locked WR stars typically possess angular momentum greater than a maximally rotating BH of equal mass for a wide range of separations.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure depicts the final spin of a WR star before collapse (a(t_WR, d)) for various binary separations. What does the rapid transition from low to high spin values signify?
choices: The impact of wind-driven angular momentum loss is negligible compared to tidal effects.
The initial spin of the WR star is the dominant factor determining its final spin.
There exists a critical separation where tidal forces become significantly stronger than wind effects, leading to rapid spin-up of the WR star.
The mass of the BH has a negligible effect on the final spin of the WR star.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure presents the expected distributions of X_eff for merging black holes, assuming negligible birth spins. What is the key feature of these distributions and its implication on the formation of gravitational wave sources?
choices: The distributions are unimodal, suggesting a single dominant formation channel for binary black holes.
The distributions are bimodal, suggesting two distinct formation channels for binary black holes: one with maximally spinning secondaries and another with slowly spinning secondaries.
The distributions peak at X_eff = 0, implying that most binary black holes are formed with negligible spins.
The shape of the distribution is highly sensitive to the initial mass ratio of the binary.
